history.content:
You will get a warning for dropping below 13 units, but you can still drop the class. 

Personally, I would drop CS70 and take it during the summer and finish up 61C. CS70 is a bit easier during the summer in the sense that it's the only class you'll have to focus on, plus you're already familiar with the course material. It would make sense to take CS70 during the summer if it's important for you to declare.

You will get a warning for dropping below 13 units.

You will get a warning for dropping below 13 units. 

Personally, I would drop CS70 and take it during the summer and finish up 61C. CS70 is a bit easier in the sense that it's the only class you'll have to focus on, plus you're already familiar with the course material. It would make sense to take CS70 during the summer if it's important for you to declare.

You will get a warning for dropping below 13 units. 

Personally, I would take CS70 during the summer and finish up 61C. CS70 is a bit easier in the sense that it's the only class you'll have to focus on, plus you're already familiar with the course material. It would make sense to take CS70 during the summer if it's important for you to declare.

I have really been struggling with CS70 this semester. I devote hours and hours to soaking up the notes, the lectures, the discussions, and the homeworks but still do horrendously bad on the midterms. Since 70 is so important for major declaration, is it feasible for me to late-drop 61C and take it during the summer?

Some context: I am currently a sophomore and already have 73.8 units (excluding the ones from this semester) under my belt. I am taking 13 units this semester, so I don't know what the implications of dropping 61C would be for me.
history.subject: CS61C Late drop?
